body.head.byline: By VIVIAN S. TOY; With Suzanne Hamlin, C. J. Hughes and Lisa Prevost

block.p: Murray Hill Co-op $795,000
MANHATTAN: 244 East 30th Street (between Second and Third Avenues), #1B
A two-bedroom, two-bath co-op. Paul Zumoff, the Corcoran Group (718) 210-4025; www.corcoran.com
MAINTENANCE: $1,154 a month
PROS: The apartment faces south onto a tree-filled garden and an ivy-covered wall. Nice touches include decorative fireplaces and three windows in the second bedroom.
CONS: Despite having two bedrooms and two baths, this apartment does not feel large.
Split-Level Cape $1,799,000
QUEENS: 110 Malba Drive, Malba

A 1949 four-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath home with 2,600 square feet of space, central air-conditioning, eat-in kitchen with oak floors and a garage in the basement. Anthony Carollo, Carollo Real Estate (718) 747-7747; www.carollorealestate.com
TAXES: $7,822 a year
PROS: A den off the kitchen receives lots of natural light. The site affords partial views of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge.
CONS: A yellow wall-to-wall carpet in the living room and a lime-green one in the dining room might not be to everyone's taste. The master bath opens onto a hallway, not the master bedroom.
Chelsea Co-op $1,200,000
MANHATTAN: 465 West 23rd Street (at 10th Avenue), #11B

A one-bedroom, one-bath apartment in a prewar doorman building that has a health club and pool. Ervin Hechavarria (212) 229-0276, Jennifer Regenstreich (212) 242-1398, JC DeNiro & Associates; www.jcdeniro.com
MAINTENANCE: $1,416 a month

PROS: This apartment has been renovated with handmade details throughout, including carved shutters and closet doors and walls painted in gold leaf. The living room has northern and western exposures and partial river views.
CONS: Although elegant, its style may not suit every buyer. The kitchen is tiny.
Cobble Hill Sanctuary $2,749,000
BROOKLYN: 249 Degraw Street (near Clinton Street)

A four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath condo, one of two in a former church, with an open living space, office, family room, storage room, darkroom and garden. Mary Goodson, Aguayo & Huebener Realty (718) 788-8200, ext. 40; www.ahrlty.com
Open house Saturday, 1 to 3 p.m.; Sunday 12 to 2 p.m.
TAXES: $4,600 a year; no common charge

PROS: With its original stained-glass windows and rose-covered facade intact, this condo is intriguingly contemporary, a mix of cozy nooks, unexpected angles and an enormous living space with a floating glass staircase and 30-foot ceiling.
CONS: The secluded decked garden in back can be reached only from the front sidewalk via a pathway at the side of the building.
Italianate Victorian $789,000
CONNECTICUT: 219 Newtown Avenue, Norwalk

A renovated 1860 Victorian with four bedrooms, two baths, original wide-plank flooring, family room with fireplace, office and a two-story barn on a half-acre. Robert Travers, Coldwell Banker (203) 858-1683; www.bobtravers.com
TAXES: $7,528 a year
PROS: The warm country kitchen opens onto a deep wraparound porch that is also accessible from the family room.
CONS: Although there is a mudroom at the back entrance, the front door opens directly into the living room. There is no master bath.
Murray Hill Co-op $795,000
MANHATTAN: 244 East 30th Street (between Second and Third Avenues), #1B
